OW_task_description__c:
This task is created by: LOA being sent to a provider, and automatically generates 5 days after LOA is sent

This task will trigger: N/A (but should be moved forward if chased and info not received)


The purpose of this task is to check that the LOA has been sent to correct place and that our information request is being processed. It’s to ensure that we do not send LOAs and then realise months later that it has been lost or rejected for any reason, and then have to start the LOA process again.


Note - if this is the second or third time that you are calling to chase a provider and they tell you that this is still being processed then don't be afraid to let them know you are considering raising a complaint. It will speed them up or they will offer to prioritise sending the information to avoid a complaint.


  • Call provider to check LOA has been received.
  • Ask the provider to confirm when the requested information will be sent and by what format.
  • If the provider tells you that the information is in the post, request that a copy of this is sent via email to amy@octopuswealth.com alternatively if they do not email then request by fax 0203 880 8054. (Faxes will also arrive in the email inbox, so always good to request is this is the only option).
  • Update salesforce with ‘Date Accepted by Provider’, ‘Provider LOA Status’ and service level agreements (SLAs) and turnaround times.
  • Write a chatter note, detailing the number you called and the person that you spoke to. This is so that when planners/ partners look at the LOA they will know the last time the information was chased.
  • This task should be pushed after each chase



If the LOA has been rejected (client action request can be used for any stage of the LOA):

  • Then in the field ‘Provider LOA Status’ - put it as rejected
  • If the LOA is rejected and we need an action from the client (e.g. to update their surname or address):
    • Manually change the LOA status as ‘LOA Rejected - Action Required from Client’.
    • Click the "More" tab next to "Stage Fields" & "New Client Action Request"
    • Create a new Client Action Request: Adding in a name to describe the request, the household, and if relevant, then the person account it is relevant too.
    • (A Client Action Request can be related to one or more LOA's)
    • Fill out the 'Client Instructions' text box with the exact instructions for the client you would want them to read in an email. This will be sent to the clients in their weekly update emails, so please make sure there is no grammar or spelling mistakes. A good example is:
      • Please could you contact Aviva to update your {ADDRESS/NI NUMBER/DOB/etc} at your earliest convenience. You can do this by {RELAY PROVIDER INSTRUCTIONS. E.G. CALL 0123456677 AND SPEAK WITH THE X DEPARTMENT QUOTING YOUR POLICY NUMBER 0390483 AND RUNNING THROUGH SOME SECURITY QUESTIONS}.
    • Complete the 'Date Requested from Client' field & the 'what we expect to receive' text box.

Once the information has been received from the provider:

  • Save the information into the clients g-drive folder under 'Policies' >> 'Active policies'.
  • Create a new folder with the naming structure "PROVIDER NAME & POLICY TYPE, (CLIENT INITIALS) --> E.g. Aviva Pension (TA)
  • Task should be closed once review info task has been completed (if all info has been received)

Note - you cant complete this task until the following fields have been completed:

  • Date Checklist Completed (Specialist)
  • Checklist Completed (Specialist) Tick box


Chatters

All chatters should contain the following information:

  1. Contact number called
  2. First and second name of who you spoke to.
  3. Date and time of call (approx. time is fine)
  4. If you get a valuation, please also get the date of the value

This task involves completing the suitability builder and providing performance data either through FE or the performance table.

 

Before completing these tasks for the first time, please familiarise yourself with the Suitability Builder Cheat Sheet here. This covers some of the FAQs around certain providers and problems you might have. Please raise if you find anything that should be added to this guide!

 

Small arrangements:

  • These only require you to add in plan charges and to highlight any guarantees or penalties. The plan also needs to be added to the suitability builder dashboard with the current value.
  • NO asset allocation or performance information is required.
  • If a small product is actively receiving investment or contributions (i.e. regular direct debit) then it needs to go through the full LOA process.

 

Self-Managed, DFM & Advised plans:

  • We are required to include performance and asset allocation in the SB but this is to come directly from the client &/or adviser &/or DFM. A reminder that it is possible to have a DFM and Adviser in place on one plan so we must be capturing all the fees that apply to the policy, including any platform derived costs (i.e. there could be 3 providers involved in one arrangement).
  • Again we are NOT required to use FE for these plans but should be taking performance and asset allocation directly from the provided report/ statement. If this is not available this is to be left out and planning will make a note in the deck.
  • For advised plans, firstly check if there is a current adviser in place. If this does not apply, be vigilant for anything on policy docs that refer to adviser charging.
  • Performance data - If we can only obtain 1y, 3y, 5y data - Please make these figures clear for the planner but do not put them in the manual performance table because the figures will pull through incorrect results

Model Portfolios

  • Check the cheat sheet for provider specific rules but we should be using the model portfolio asset allocation and performance where possible
  • These can often be found online


Defined benefit pensions, Annuities, and protection (unless they have investments associated with them) plans do not require a suitability builder. In this case, just write n/a in the Suitability builder Link field in Salesforce, and complete this task.



Cash ISAs, Fixed Term Deposits, VCTs, EISs and SEISs need to be added to the Dashboard with a value and owner - but this does not require a full Suitability Builder (funds, performance, asset allocation, fees).


Builder Part 1 - Adding plans to the Dashboard

 

The first step is to open the suitability builder for this advice. 

Go to the clients folder, Advice Meetings, and choose the correct piece of advice (usually the most recent, but check on the household to see which advice is most relevant if there are two running concurrently. Ask a planner if you’re unsure). 

In there, go to Research - Calculations, and the builder should be there. If not, make a copy of the master here and save in the right place.


Once in the builder, add the client’s preferred names where indicated, and then add the policy you’re working on into the dashboard - leaving the recommendation column blank.

Please ensure to add Cash ISAs, Fixed Term Deposits, VCTs, EISs and SEISs with their values. However, we do not need to complete a full Suitability Builder (funds, performance, asset allocation, fees).

Then click Builder Tools in the bar at the top, then Create Calculators. You may need to log in to Google and repeat this step.


This will create a hyperlink on the provider name, so click this, then click Unhide.




Builder Part 2 - Filling out the plan’s builder


At this point, it is useful to have the LOA builder and policy folder for this policy open.


Add the date of the valuations in (from the date of valuations in the LOA builder), and your name in the Completed by box.


Add the separate funds and their valuations into the columns (you can find this in the policy information). 

Ideally find the OCFs/transaction charges from the fund factsheets, or if they’re explicitly listed in the LOA builder, but if not the fees columns can wait until after completing the FE analysis (see later steps). 

Remember to include any cash at the bottom.




Next, complete the ‘All fees’ section. You should refer to the LOA builder here, especially where the planner confirms fees. You only need to put a % or a value in each section (not both). Make sure the summary shows values, not errors. OCF fees don’t get readded in this section (as they’re in the first grid). 


Include here any policy or admin fees under policy fee, any transfer or exit fees under transfer, any advice or discretionary management fees under advice, and combine any other outstanding ones under other. Initial fees are NOT needed.


If you need to calculate tiered charging, please make a copy of this spreadsheet to help you

Builder Part 3 - FE


Now, move on to the FE analysis. Log in using lastpass. Click onto portfolios and create a new one (or, find the one already made if you’re just updating it by searching).


Funds/Shares


﻿When entering funds into FE, if you find that the majority are in FE but a few are not, don't start over but instead create a portfolio for the funds that are available. You can then add this portfolio as one fund into the suitability builder, which would account for nearly 90%ish of the actual policy. You would then add the few funds not in FE manually using a performance table and work out the weighted asset allocation." 




Add each fund into the portfolio using this magnifier with green plus, and typing in the ISIN or fund name. Make sure that you definitely have the correct fund (check name, provider type (income or accumulation) and the class (the letter associated with it)), and click the green tick. If the funds aren’t available, see later section to provide performance data.


Make sure ‘View & store holdings’ is set to UNITS, and add the number of units in for each fund. If you don't have the units held you can use GBP Value and values instead - just make sure the categories are aligned first as if you reselect after you'll have to fill the numbers out again!


It's also worth checking that the GBP value of the portfolio you have entered corresponds to roughly to the value we have received from the provider. If these are very different, you may have selected the wrong fund.


Cash


Add any cash under the ‘Currencies’ section.


Saving


Then click save. Choose the Client, and make sure Permissions is set to ‘Public [Full access]. Save it in the format Last Name, First Inital - Provider Policy type eg Glanville, H - Aviva Pension. We should use xxx Pension as standard even if it is a GPP or SIPP. Also use ISA or GIA as standard.


If there are multiple policies for same provider, please add policy numbers in brackets to differentiate e.g. Bloggs, J - Aviva Pension (TKXXXX)


Long Scan


 Then click Long Scan. If you didn’t previously complete the fees section in the builder, you can find them here. For each fund, click on the little blue card to bring up the factsheet. From here, add the OCF from the fund summary, or go to the ‘MIFID details’ tab and find the ongoing charge and transaction charges there.

  • when you get transaction charges from FE for the builder, the FE MiFID page needs to be saved to the g-drive for each fund.


From the Long Scan, click ‘PDF Portrait’. Save this down in the folder ‘Research - Investment’ under the client’s advice meeting folder. 


Remember to log out of FE when you’re done!! 


Back to the Builder - Asset Allocation (See Non-Standard AA Sheet)


Copy the asset allocation from page 5 here into the suitability builder. Make sure the total is 100% - if not, add/subtract from the ‘other’ category as necessary. Be sure that the ‘Other’ category has the lowest % as possible. Use the Long Scan to figure out where the other has come from e.g UK equity fund - round other up to UK equities.


If the asset allocation is unavailable, or all undisclosed or other, fill out the asset allocation using the fund factsheets. If there’s only one fund you can copy this in directly, if there’s more than one click the ‘toggle asset allocation button’ and copy them in individually. If the categories don’t align easily with the ones in the builder, ask a planner which category they can go in. If funds are split into further funds you’ll need to create additional calculators to ensure the allocation is accurate.



Performance table


If the funds weren’t available in FE, click the ‘Performance table’ button, authorise as required, and click the tab which generates at the bottom. Use the fund factsheets to complete the red boxes. Add the date that the fund factsheets were created (should be on them at the top), and the performance data. Make sure that you’re using the correct figures - not the benchmark fund, and not the 5y, 3y etc data - you want the full years to date for your fund. 


Once the builder is complete (ie an asset allocation and performance data have been provided in some format), copy the link to the builder into the SF field, and tag #ops4eye to get the builder 4eyed. Once this has been approved, complete the task.

It’s possible that a household may have a task to send a DB Triage document with it being unclear which client to send to, or the task may be directly associated with one client. If the task is with the household, send the document to both clients; if it is with the person, send it to that person; if both of these types are open at the same time, talk to the partner to determine who should receive it. If they've not yet signed TOB, the task may still be required, please discuss this with the partner or compliance if they are unsure. In this case, complete both tasks when you send the document. Do not send it twice.


  • Check the 'DB Triage' Fields on the person account. If they've already been filled out in the last year, complete this task, and don't resend it.
  • If the pension is under the Pension Protection Fund, or a member of the Public Sector Transfer Club, complete this task, and don't send the DB TRiage document.
  • Send the DB triage document to the client using the email template here
  • Update the date DB triage document was sent field on the person account

  • Mark task as complete


For further context, Triage is two things:

  1. Sending the triage document
  2. The client confirming they have read and understood it.

They aren’t required to do step 2, unless we want to provide DB advice to them. If this is the case, they must confirm they’ve read and understood so that we can have more detailed discussions with them.

Name: Fulfilment Investment Checks
OW_task_description__c:
Objective: the purpose of this task is to make sure that funds have been received and invested as per our recommendation.


Once finished, complete the screen on the top right of the fulfilment. This will auto complete the task.


Things to check


  • Chatter - the first place to check when completing this task is the chatter on the financial product. This will highlight any changes that might have been made since the fulfilment was set up or any of-process details to pick up. Make sure any instructions in the chatter have been picked up and applied.
  • Investment value - Confirm received value is in line with expectation (we allow for +/- 5% variation). Any lump sums should be received for the exact amount. If the value received is +/-5% (or more) ensure you have checked for a cause* of the difference and leave a comment accordingly. Where payments have been made in installments by the client, check to see that all installments have been received
  • Investment mandate - Confirm on Hubwise that the correct portfolio has been selected. You can see the intended investment mandate is for the product within the Financial Product in the ‘Octopus Products’ section. You can check the selected portfolio in the ‘Portfolio’ section of the ‘Account Details’ tab in Hubwise.

  • Phasing - Where the investment was supposed to be phased, we need to check that the phase has gone ahead as intended. You can check to see what phasing was recommended in the ‘Phasing’ section of the Recommendation. You should check within the ‘Manage Phased Investment’ section in Hubwise and make sure this matches our expectation of how the phases will proceed. Where there has been a phase added to a previous phase, we should check that the amount remaining from the previous phase and the new amount is amalgamated and phased over the longer of the remaining periods.

  • Fees - Confirm the correct fees have been applied:
  1. Confirm any applicable advice set up fee has been deducted (£)
    1. Confirm any applicable transfer fee (%) has been deducted
    2. Confirm the correct ongoing charges have been submitted (i.e. standard tiering or flat fee)

You should check within the plan statement within hubwise that these have been taken and are appropriately labelled. You can view the intended fees under the ‘Instructions’ section of the fulfilment in Salesforce.


  • Updating Salesforce - Make sure that the status of the source/ceding Financial Product has been set to closed if the full transfer is complete. If it was a full transfer, the ceding product’s G Drive folder should be moved from the ‘Active’ plans subfolder to ‘Historic’.


Once all of the above have been checked and any discrepancies have been corrected, with incidents/ P&Ls raised where appropriate, the task can be completed.


Troubleshooting


Difference in values


Where the expected value differs from the actual received value, this may be due to:


  • The expected value is significantly old. I.e. it was obtained during data gathering X number of months ago and the value difference is justified given market performance over that time
  • It is a transfer from an arrangement that was receiving regular or known contributions prior to transfer, and therefore, the additional contributions caused an increase in value
  • A known exit penalty was applied on transfer by the ceding provider (in this instance, it is wise to flag to a planner to check that this was expected or unknown)

The difference in expected value should be investigated and comments should be added in chatter. Where a mistake will require further action, make sure a task is created and the planner/partner are notified where appropriate.


It might be useful to check the ceding portfolio in FE, or the relevant performance of invested portfolios to see whether a difference in value is due to investment performance. The steps below detail how this can be done.


  • Go into FE and find the portfolio used for LOA analysis. 
  • Search for the plan in ‘Portfolios’ and click add. 
  • Load the interactive performance chart, then go to ‘Performance Settings’ and change the performance period to ‘User Specified’, use the valuation date in from the file and the date of the transfer. 
  • This will give you a chart which you should print and save to the g-drive for the product. It will also have a cumulative performance figure from the date specified. It's expected that this is going to come up as -5% or worse. If it's broadly in line with the difference in values seen before then it's fine, if it's very different then escalate to a planner. 
  • If the portfolio isn't in FE then we need the factsheet from the provider with the performance.


Phasing


  • You should first check the ‘Manage Phased Investment’ section in Hubwise to see why any mistakes have been applied
  • You can also check to see that the correct amount of cash has been ringfenced using the guide here
  • If the phasing instruction looks wrong, raise a ticket with Freshdesk and keep the Fulfilment Investment Checks task open until it is corrected. 
  • Once the first month of phasing has completed and looks correct, we can proceed with completing the task, as we don't continue to monitor phasing beyond the first month. Raise an incident if relevant for any errors in processing (either by us or Hubwise). A P&L calculation should also be raised if our error could have resulted in client detriment.


Fees


  • If the initial fee(s) haven’t been automatically deducted as instructed, raise a ticket with Freshdesk to investigate why
  • If necessary or instructed by Hubwise, instruct an ad-hoc initial fee via Hubwise and keep this task open until it has been deducted. Raise an incident if relevant for any errors in processing (either by us or Hubwise).


External product EOW fulfillment


Please update the following:

  • The financial product notes (with a date)
  • The LOA builder - noted as an update rather than an overwrite!

Name: Submit fulfilment
OW_task_description__c:
For all fulfilment except Protection and EoW:

 

Fulfilment is now ready for submission via Hubwise/Hartley/Octopus Investments. You should refer to the fulfilment checklist for the following:

 

  • Fulfilment type (i.e. lump sum/regular/transfer (cash)/transfer (in-specie)/surrender) 
  • Adviser charges
  • Investment mandate
  • Phasing instructions
  • Required forms
  • Client bank details 

For small arrangements (<£2,000) - Ensure that no transfer fee is applied

 

For withdrawals once submitted, you should email the client to confirm we've processed the withdrawal using this template https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ziyJTukOuTcXBP-t6e_KhMI4kha4Q7OpshQuB6R7oYE/edit

 

Complete all of the sections within “Submit fulfilment” in the fulfilment checklist whilst submitting the application via the relevant provider.

 

Complete this task once the application has been submitted to the relevant provider. 

 

Note: for any SIPP fulfilment, this task also incorporates sending the relevant forms to Hartley via email. All forms should be emailed to newbusiness@hartleypensions.com 

 

Reminder, you can access the fulfilment forms guide here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1AS3GAmBqCfArD9a6MYUBTfhuiSBnBVBjmU9yvN2z0o4/edit

 

For all Protection:

 

This task has been triggered because we have completed medical questions with the client.

 

Depending on the provider, the specialist that undertook the call will have either compiled the client’s answers on a data capture form or direct into an online application system. Where a form has been used, the data should now be input into the relevant online application system.

 

For each provider, the process is slightly different, however, at this stage you should ensure that the application is correctly submitted for underwriting. Prior to submission, double check that the correct application is being submitted by comparing the application details (usually online) with the information that the planner originally stated in the “Setup Fulfilment” section of the checklist.

 

If you are unsure of the provider’s processes, you should google their online support team’s tel number who will be best placed to help (the specialist/planning team has limited experience with protection providers to date).

 

Once submitted successfully, email the client with the following template: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1yIx7jSfSeurapGrQ6j1MaTwnt8rmUq3_EzEbLhgvLA0/edit

 

Complete the “submit forms” and section complete sections of the fulfilment checklist.

 

Complete the task.


For EoW

We should have received signed EoW forms. These now need to be sent to the provider. This may be via email or post - you should contact the provider or check previous chatter / fulfilment checklist to find out which. When updating expression of wishes for an Octopus Wealth SIPP, upload the EoW document to the Hubwise portal as 'miscellaneous document'.

Once these have been sent, add a comment to the task and push it back a week so that we can check the provider has accepted them. Continue to do this until the provider confirms the new beneficiary has been applied to the policy. When this is confirmed, complete the task and update the checklist as necessary.

Name: Chase client payment
OW_due_date__c: First chase should be 2 weeks, then move forward 7 days thereafter
OW_task_description__c:
First step should be to check Hubwise to see if we have received the expected funds from the client.


If no:


Chase the client via email every 7 days.

Best practice is to use the payment details template each time but change the intro wording to “Just a friendly reminder….”. You can also search in Helpscout for the last version of this email sent to the client, and copy and paste the text into a new email. If copy and pasting, double check which bank details are in Salesforce and if they match the email.


If the client responds in the meantime to say they've made the payment, but we can't yet see it in Hubwise, that's because it usually takes 1 working day for Hubwise to make the payment visible. In this instance, you should respond to the client with this holding email: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1C5DviWCEE6H6Y_YRtvdtNFVR8WJ8SQYzmh-VG_cw6TE/edit, and set the payment status to ‘Funds on their way’ using the screen in the top right of the fulfilment.


Once we have received payment into Hubwise, update the screen on the top right of the fulfilment. This includes:

Update IO (for new plans, you will need to add the plan using the guides https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1cUnD8UQS2JZj5mCt5fQCMXQ3-HASQgLH-pGVRGM8LY4/edit#gid=0)

Add IO ID to Salesforce products (NOVA products only)

Check that all Salesforce products are up to date (correct status and account numbers and IO iD etc)

Email client confirmation of payment received (only for lump sums & transfers - NOT for direct debits/regular contributions)

For all payment types, check that the Hubwise label for the transaction matches the transaction types. For lump sums this should be "Top-up", for direct debits this should be "Regular contribution" and for transfers, it should say "Transfer". Tax relief should also be obviously identified.

If the label looks wrong

> raise a ticket with Hubwise via Freshdesk to request that they update the label to X.

> Record the ticket number and notes in the fulfilment hubwise links box


Once the above is done, this task will auto complete.

Name: Chase transfer
OW_task_description__c:
This task should be kept open while chasing the ceding provider. The first chase should be carried out 1 week after submission.

The first stage in all chasing should be to check online with Hubwise to see if funds have arrived. If funds have arrived for the transfer, update the screen at the top of the fulfilment which includes:

  • Update IO
  • Update Salesforce products
  • Email client confirmation of payment received

For all payment types, check that the Hubwise label for the transaction matches the transaction types. For lump sums this should be "Top-up", for direct debits this should be "Regular contribution" and for transfers, it should say "Transfer". Tax relief should also be obviously identified.

If the label looks wrong

  • raise a ticket with Hubwise via Freshdesk to request that they update the label to X.
  • Record the ticket number and notes in the fulfilment chatter so the checking planner can see the request has been made.


Once the above is done, this task will auto-complete.


However, if we've not yet received transfer funds, you should call a provider to chase the transfer (email is fine if no call centre). After the first chase, make clear notes within chatter to confirm the telephone number you called, who you spoke with, and the outcome of the call. Mark task as incomplete and move forward 7 days as standard (unless there is a more suitable date following information from the provider). We should actively chase the ceding provider and, if necessary, Hubwise each week until transfer funds received. 


Important note: a provider may tell you that they have sent the transfer funds to Hubwise already but they aren't visible in Hubwise yet. In this instance, you should record the call notes via chatter and move the task forward. Record the payment status as “Funds on their way” using the screen at the top right of the fulfilment.


Partial Transfers: On the first chaser, please check that the partial transfer instruction has been added correctly - i.e. get the ceding provider to check the instruction & confirm on the chatter - Once this has been done, this will prevent issues further down the line


 It can take 3-5 working days for Hubwise to receive funds and then they have internal checks that need to be carried out before they can apply the funds to the client's account. That said, you should use your judgement and if it seems the payment is taking too long (i.e. more than 1-2 weeks), you should contact Hubwise to ask them to give you an update. Hubwise should be contacted via Freshdesk.


Chatters

All chatters should contain the following information:

  1. Contact number called
  2. First and second name of who you spoke to.
  3. Date and time of call (approx. time is fine)
  4. If you get a valuation, please also get the date of the value

 

We should also be making sure that we are recording all calls.

Name: Create Annual Review Deck
OW_task_description__c:
This task is triggered by: Annual review factfind being completed

This task will generate: Planner Four eye and partner review


Note - This task encompasses more than just creating the deck, so all of the preparation and research too. 


Download IO Valuation report

  • This report will be used for the performance figures in the annual review.
  • Log into IO and download a Valuation report, Include partner and family so that all accounts from the household appear on one report.
  • Save PDF to annual review folder in the gdrive under: Research – Investments
  • Review the figures on the report and sense check the gain/loss % to see if this is reasonable. 
  • Note – if the factfind was only just completed then the valuations for external products/cash may be wrong.
  • Tick the box when this has been saved


List Voyant updates

  • Any changes (other than valuations) that will affect the Lifeline. i.e. changes to salary, retirement date, investment profile growth rates etc.
  • Update any changes that are required following the last meeting, use the newly completed fact find. If moving to passive for example then ensure charges are updated, along with valuations. This field is here to show the amendments that have been met from the original lifeline. 
  • Update Voyant.
  • Check if they have requested any alternative scenarios, if so make sure these are included.
  • Update information into Voyant, if no concurrent advice and no alternative scenarios requested then it will just be a base line
  • When this is done tick the box, this will generate a Four eye task for planners to check Voyant


Annual review deck link

  • Make a copy of the annual review deck and save it to the g drive folder
  • Template annual review deck: Client drive/ [Templates]/ Annual review/ Annual review template
  • Take any slides for the main deck, for any concurrent advice.


Annual review – Suitability builder

  • Copy and save suitability builder to annual review folder in gdrive. Note – if there is concurrent advice make sure the same builder is linked on the annual review and the suitability.
  • Paste suitability builder link into the annual review
  • Use IO report to update SB with current valuations of plans, add this to the dashboard and use provider as Octopus Wealth


Supporting calculations

  • Link these to the annual review


Set up fulfilment

  • Make sure any fulfilment has been set up
  • Note – do not duplicate this if it also going to be linked to a suitability case
  • Tick the box to show fulfilment has been set up

Name: Create and send LOAs
OW_task_description__c:
For this task, you will need:

 


  • Client's LOA Builder
  • Provider Database https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1U0fB-0LhoL3nZcCbQu_Hr81zmoPfmSDysYccibyBz5w/edit#gid=279658702
  • 'PDFSam Basic' for merging PDFs (download page here https://pdfsam.org/download-pdfsam-basic/)

 

 

For context: LOA refers to a 'Letter of authority' (LOA), and a similar document we use is a 'Transfer of Servicing' (TOS). For simplicity, LOA & TOS work in a similar way - they are signed documents that we send to providers. Once accepted, they allow us to obtain information (valuations, charges information etc.) about our clients financial products, such as their pensions or ISAs. We need this information in order to provide financial advice to them.

 

The difference between the two is that TOS gives us full control and servicing rights over their plan for us to make changes, and allows us to see live information on portals (valuations, illustrations etc). An LOA however will only allow us to receive plan information from the provider upon request.

 

By default, we send TOS documents, however there will be some instances to send an LOA instead of TOS (this is covered later on in this guide).

 



Setting up LOA/TOS page in Salesforce

 

Make sure the task is in your name.

 

Go to the clients household account in Salesforce, and under the 'profile' tab, find the 'Financial Accounts' section, and click 'New'.

 

 

 

 

Select the relevant financial product - at this stage, it will be Pre-LOA (DC Pension, ISA, Protection, DB Pension).

 

Enter in product name using this convention:


Provider Type | Surname Initial

for example:

Aviva Pension | Smith T


If we have name of the employer for the pension we can add it in the bracket for example:

Aviva (HSBC) Pension | Smith T.


Add Primary owner, Joint owner (if applicable), Subtype (most relevant from dropdown options), Household, Status set to 'Open', and tick 'create LOA' box.

 

NOTE: When adding in household, ensure a household account is entered that starts with OW number (and not a personal account), to ensure the correct household is linked to the product, and it is not missed.

 

Add in provider details (have to press search in left side box to see options, the right side box has drop down options). If the provider needed is not visible when searching in left side box, request for it to be added, and then you can add in the relevant corresponding contact details in the right side box.

 

NOTE: We may have been provided with client's workplace details, rather than the provider that administers that workplace pension, in which case, select 'Unknown Provider' until the provider is confirmed. We may also have employer benefits noted in the client’s Fact find, for example for their workplace protection policies. For these we can add the provider in as ‘Employer benefit’ in Salesforce.

 

In these cases, we need to confirm who administers the product, in order to determine where we should send an LOA/TOS to. We can find this out either by contacting the workplace, using pension tracing https://www.gov.uk/find-pension-contact-details (for pension products), or by confirming with the client directly. If unsure, raise with another specialist to confirm what needs doing.

 

Add account number, value (won't apply if protection), and any relevant notes that would be useful (protection details, date of value etc.) If we don't have account number & value for now, leave blank, we may be waiting to receive these from client.

 

Hit save

 

Repeat the above steps for all accounts that are relevant from the client's Fact Find.

 

 

Sending the LOA


Some providers don't accept LOAs - such as AJ Bell YouInvest, Interactive Investor, Barclays Smart Investor. For these ones, you'll need to email the client directly using this template. https://docs.google.com/document/d/1DddRJsbxGUcHzDmC1nWxdmLCpKdxYrp0paKoiHoaRL0/edit


 

Now that the record is setup in Salesforce, we need to create the LOA/TOS document that we will send. Go to the client's 'LOA builder', which is found in their G drive folder, within the LOA/TOS folder.

 

If the builder is already in the client's folder: go to LOA&TOS and open the builder, and see notes below.

 

If the LOA Builder file isn’t already in the clients LOA/TOS folder: you’ll need to add it. Go to this link https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1rVsyf_TbiH1IXBUeOYkvdsp57_euJpmB and make a copy of the builder that is there. Then, move this copied file to the relevant clients folder, within their 'LOA&TOS' folder.

 

Open this document and fill in the fields - Adviser, full names, DOB, NI number (if we have this), address, and children (if applicable/needed) - this should all be found in their Fact Find.

 

Additionally, you will need to go to the 'Provider Database' tab along the bottom, then hover over the little red triangle next to #REF!, and press 'allow access'

 

 

 

Adding in plan information to dashboard:

 

Now you need to add the relevant plans to the list within the dashboard. In most cases, when you search for a provider in the 'Provider' column, there will be a drop down menu with the necessary provider options needed.

 

However, if there is not already the provider you need there, you will need to:

Call up the necessary provider (you can Google the most relevant number for the provider and team), and find out: If they accept LOAs (some won't, and we need to obtain information another way), IF YES - confirm the needed format they need it in (via email or physical post). Take down the relevant email address or postal address.

 

Next, go to the provider database: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1U0fB-0LhoL3nZcCbQu_Hr81zmoPfmSDysYccibyBz5w/edit#gid=279658702

 

Scroll to the bottom, and add in the new providers information you found. We will need the provider name, the policy type (Pension, ISA etc.), letter type (note: FS pension is used for DB pensions), telephone number, email address if sending in electronically, physical address if posting in, and the format of the LOA needed (column for this found at the far right of database).

Once you have added the necessary information to the database, you can go back to the LOA builder and choose it within the dropdown options in the provider column, as the database and LOA builders are linked.

 

Now, fill in the information in the other 3 columns (policy type, number, and holder).

 

 

 

To generate the LOA/TOS:

 

In the dashboard, tick the box next to the policies you want to create a LOA or TOS for, then click the small ‘L’ button to create a LOA document, or small ‘T’ if you’re generating a TOS document. This will be saved into the G-drive LOA&TOS folder. 

 

There will be cases NOT to send TOS, such as when the client already has their own financial adviser in place. To check if they do, go to the 'Opportunities' section directly under the 'Work' tab in the client's household, click into their opportunity, and find the section 'Current adviser in place':

If the answer is yes - only send an LOA, and not TOS. If you are unsure which to send, check with a planner.

 

Once you have created the LOA or TOS, you’ll then need to send this to either Alex or Fred via email, who will add the signature on behalf of the client. When they return this back to you, save it into the client's ‘Signed LOA&TOS folder'.

 

Check before sending to Alex/Fred if the LOA/TOS being sent needs to be posted, as these should be sent to Alex. You can check the needed format of LOA/TOS in the far right of the provider database.

 

 

Sending via post:

 

Send the LOA/TOS to Alex, along with the cover letter, and he will post this out. To create the cover letter, in the LOA Builder dashboard, tick the box next to the relevant policy and click the small ‘CL’ button at the bottom. This will generate a cover letter and a checklist of information for the provider to answer.

 

He will then send you back a scanned copy of the merged file, and this needs to be saved to the G drive in the client's 'LOA/TOS sent to provider' file, and Salesforce updated (see below).

 

Sending via email:

 

Generate a cover letter as above, and go to PDFsam Basic, click ‘Merge’, then click ‘Add’. First add the cover letter you made, then add the signed LOA received back from Fred second. Click ‘Run’, and save this to the ‘LOA&TOS Sent to Provider’ folder in g-drive. 

 

In HelpScout, create a new conversation. Click on the small speech bubble icon (last icon in the bar containing attachments/font changes) and select ‘LoA: Send LoA to Provider’. Copy paste the given subject format into the email subject and replace the information as appropriate. Remember to remove this from the email body. Attach the merged file, add in the provider email as from the database, assign to anyone, then send.

 



Updating Salesforce:

 

Once the LOA/TOS has been sent:

 

Go to the relevant LOA/TOS page - these can be found within the clients household account towards the bottom, within the LOAs section. Once they have been linked to a piece of advice, you can also find LOAs there within the 'Related Items' tab.

 

 

 

Once in the LOA page, fill in the 'Sent to Provider' section as needed:

 

 

Leave a chatter note that LOA/TOS was sent, on which date & in which format.

 

 

Adding checklists to Salesforce:

 

Lastly we need to add in the LOA builder URL link to the Salesforce page.

 

Back in the LOA builder, click ‘Builder Tools’ at the top, then ‘Create Checklists’. You may have to sign in to G-drive, then re-click ‘Builder Tools’ -> ‘Create Checklists’.

 

The plan you added should now be in bold, and underlined. Hover over this, and click the link that appears below it. Once in this page, copy the URL link and add this into Salesforce (see pictures below).

 

For reference, you can see all the policy checklist tabs that have been generated along the bottom of the builder page.

 

 

 

 

 

Tick off task (make sure it is in your name before doing so).

If the ISA fulfilment has already been submitted, you should raise a FD ticket with Hubwise to update their record of "ISA allowance available" for the new ISA.

If the client passes the TransUnion check - update the Experian field to 'Pass', enter the date the check was carried out on and press Save.

 

If the client fails the TransUnion check -

  • Update to 'Refer', write any notes for the MRLO to see, enter the date the check was carried out on and press Save. This will generate a task to ‘Request Identity Documents’ (description on task).

 

Once the Identity documents have been received back we can review them. We need to check the following:

  • Check info we hold on file that has been used for checks is correct
    • DOB, name or address could've been mistyped
  • Proof of address documents are in date.
    • Identity Docs (eg driving licence: Not expired
    • Other docs (eg utility bill): dated within 3 months (12 for council tax)
    • If it’s a pdf (has to be source pdf, not picture if it’s banking etc)
    • If scan/photo of doc, need whole doc not zoomed in
    • Has to be an actual statement or bill (ie. not normal letter from bank) 
  • Proof of address documents match address we have on file.
    • If not we should confirm correct address and rerun with the correct one (flag to partner if address differs)
  • Confirm proof of identity matches client
    • If we request a selfie - this can be done by Ops
    • If client seen on video - see if you can find meeting recording and confirm identity matches
  • If seen face to face - contact the partner to confirm identity is correct
    • There is the 'Review Identity documents' task that goes to them which you can use here
  • Validate proof of identity document (this should be a passport)
    • Go to https://worldcheck.refinitiv.com & run a passport check
  • Under Check Types, go to Passport check
    • Fill out all info and follow instructions
    • If this is validated then save passport check report to AML folder

 

If these are all passed we can then move AML check to Pass following review & complete notes section outlining all the above

Review Identity Docs task in Partners name can be completed

 

Diagram to explain flow here: https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1jDWikNZoMaeePpVW0HrBAjBvaf6gxl8GLwmiMAYXFLQ/edit

 

 

WC1:

 

  1. Access the WC1 website ( https://worldcheck.refinitiv.com/)
  2. Log in (shared Amy log in details saved in Last Pass)
  3. Select registration key 'New Team Registration'
  4. Enter (ignore titles Mrs/Mr etc) client full name (including middle name), select gender, enter date of birth, country location and nationality (you can ignore place of birth)
  5. Check the box to enable ongoing screening
  6. Click 'Screen'
  7. Select 'Export' and 'Case report' - download
  8. Upload to AML folder

If no WC1 matches: Update the WC1 to Pass and enter the completed date.

 

If there are WC1 matches:

  1. Use this document that lays out rules from disproving potential matches
  • See if we can gather evidence from client to disprove match.
  • e.g. proof that they were living elsewhere at time or had a different job to a PEP match
    • Write notes explaining how you have disproved match in WC1 & in SF
      • Upload to AML folder
      • You can use meeting recordings to compare images to clients
    • Then mark any matches as false
    • Select 'Export' and 'Case report' - download
  1. If you cannot disprove the matches, update the WC1 to Fail, add any notes as to why the client failed, and enter the completed date. The MLRO will have a task to review this. 
  • This should be a very last resort. It is very unlikely that this would be the case.
    • I would flag with someone from ops before moving to fail.

 

 

HTAR Matrix: 

 

  • If the HTAR Matrix Risk Level fields are not filled out, refresh the page. If this doesn't change then flag it on "prod-salesforce channel."
  • If the HTAR matrix is anything other than Average risk, check to see that the “MLRO to review HTAR Matrix” task has generated for MRLO.
  • If client flagged as HTAR then request identity docs using this template
  • Tag partner and planner (if case assigned to one) to flag this as they will need to have a discussion on what is required to ensure client is OK to proceed
    • This will depend on advise being given so there is no blanket rule as to what is required.

 

Link to HTAR Matrix: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1BH_tMEZ2wXYZbPs5hOYpjyYQStSBvB2xi9VChSVHAys/edit#gid=695178989

Name: Validate Client Profile Updates
OW_task_description__c:
Validation Process


Navigate to Household > Profile Updates. You will see that each FF object has a “Validated” Column, if this is blank then it is a new entry and the record needs to be validated. 


Click into the FF record, and you’ll see the data stored in it and the Validation Section. 


Validated Options 


  • Validated - Marking a record as Validated will push the changes into the corresponding SF record, or it will create a new SF record if one does not already exist.
  • Rejected - This will reject the changes and the client’s profile will revert back to the most recent validated record. 
  • Confirm Deletion - The client has deleted a record from their portal. If you confirm this deletion it will be removed from SF
  • Overwritten - This option is only ever selected automatically when a client makes multiple changes to the same record. 


Once all outstanding FF records have been either Validated or Rejected you will be able to close of the task off and be able to make changes to SF records as normal. 


If you believe that the profile has been completed, change the status to Up-to-date


Profile Status


This status is purely for internal operations visibility, the status will be updated automatically where possible, but otherwise, it’s a manual status that you can use to indicate the status of the profile. No automation will be triggered by changing this status. 


  • Update Required - The profile needs to be updated but the client has not yet been informed of this. This is the default status when a Household is first created and will revert back to this status once they have accepted scope. You can also move it to this stage manually if there is every a requirement for the client to update the profile
  • Sent to Client(s) - Designates that clients are aware that they need to update their profile. For Disco’s this will update automatically once a client it first sent the profile. 
  • Updated by Client (Validations Outstanding) - The client has made changes to their profile but they have not marked it as complete. 
  • Completed by Client (Validations Outstanding) - The client has made changes to their profile and marked it as complete. 

Up-to-date - Manually select this stage once we have everything we need. It will remain in the stage until we need a new update or the client spontaneously updates their profile.

Name: Send LOA to Provider
OW_task_description__c:
Exceptions

No need to send LOAs/email client for current or savings accounts.


Sending the LOA


Some providers don't accept LOAs - such as Cash ISAs, NS&I, AJ Bell YouInvest, Interactive Investor, Barclays Smart Investor, or for products like direct equities. For these ones, you'll need to email the client directly using this template. https://docs.google.com/document/d/1DddRJsbxGUcHzDmC1nWxdmLCpKdxYrp0paKoiHoaRL0/edit


We also don't LOA overseas pensions.


Now that the record is setup in Salesforce, we need to create the LOA/TOS document that we will send. Go to the client's 'LOA builder', which is found in their G drive folder, within the LOA/TOS folder.

 

If the builder is already in the client's folder: go to LOA&TOS and open the builder, and see notes below.

 

If the LOA Builder file isn’t already in the clients LOA/TOS folder: you’ll need to add it. Go to this link and make a copy of the builder that is there. Then, move this copied file to the relevant clients folder, within their 'LOA&TOS' folder.

 

Open this document and fill in the fields - Adviser, full names, DOB, NI number (if we have this), address, and children (if applicable/needed) - this should all be found on their salesforce profile.

 

 

Adding in plan information to dashboard:

 

Now you need to add the relevant plans to the list within the dashboard. In most cases, when you search for a provider in the 'Provider' column, there will be a drop down menu with the necessary provider options needed. We don't need to add Cash ISAs or NS&I here.

 

However, if there is not already the provider you need there, you will need to:

Call up the necessary provider (you can Google the most relevant number for the provider and team), and find out: If they accept LOAs (some won't, and we need to obtain information another way), IF YES - confirm the needed format they need it in (via email or physical post). Take down the relevant email address or postal address.

 

Next, go to the provider database: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1U0fB-0LhoL3nZcCbQu_Hr81zmoPfmSDysYccibyBz5w/edit#gid=279658702

 

Scroll to the bottom, and add in the new providers information you found. We will need the provider name, the policy type (Pension, ISA etc.), letter type (note: FS pension is used for DB pensions), telephone number, email address if sending in electronically, physical address if posting in, and the format of the LOA needed (column for this found at the far right of database).

Once you have added the necessary information to the database, you can go back to the LOA builder and choose it within the dropdown options in the provider column, as the database and LOA builders are linked.

 

Now, fill in the information in the other 3 columns (policy type, number, and holder).

 

 

 

To generate the LOA/TOS:

 

Our default is to send a Transfer of Servicing (TOS) request to the provider, however if the client has an adviser in place already then we must only send an LOA, we only send LOAs for a DB scheme. You can check this on the clients ‘Opportunity’ and looking for the field ‘Current Advisor in place’ (see below picture). If you are unsure which to send, check with a planner.

 

Also check the instructions in the Opportunity page > "List of LOAs & Status' and the partner might give instructions on what they want done.

 

In the dashboard, tick the box on the left of the policies you want to create a LOA or TOS for, then click the large ‘create selected LOAs’ button to create a LOA document, or the large ‘create selected ToS’ button if you’re generating a TOS document. This will be saved into the G-drive LOA&TOS folder. 

 


Once you have created the LOA or TOS, you need to add the client’s signature to it & the date. We retrieve the signature from the clients signed TOB. ‘Person Account’ >> ‘Related’ tab > Click on the terms of business which has been signed > then copy the whole URL link under ‘Signature image’ > paste this into the web, this usually works best on Safari instead of chrome’ > then copy this image of the signature onto the LOA/TOS in the signature box. Once this has been done, save it into he client's ‘Signed LOA&TOS folder'.

If the client has had a different name previously (eg a maiden name) please add this in in case their name hasn't been changed, eg Amy Smith (nee Farringdon).

 

Tag @specialists in chatter and ask them too 4eye it/ check it for any errors. Once this has been approved then you should check the needed format of LOA/TOS in the far right of the provider database.




Sending via post:

 

In chatter tag #post with a link to the LOA/TOS and whoever is in the office will post this out.

 

Sending via email:

  

In HelpScout, create a new conversation. Click on the small speech bubble icon (last icon in the bar containing attachments/font changes) and select ‘LoA: Send LoA to Provider’. Copy paste the given subject format into the email subject and replace the information as appropriate. Remember to remove this from the email body. Attach the merged file, add in the provider email as from the database, assign to anyone, then send.

 



Updating Salesforce:

 

Once the LOA/TOS has been sent:

 

Go to the relevant LOA/TOS page - these can be found within the clients household account towards the bottom, within the LOAs section. Once they have been linked to a piece of advice, you can also find LOAs there within the 'Related Items' tab.

 

 

 

Once in the LOA page, fill in the 'Sent to Provider' section as needed:

 

If the information has been requested from the client, set the status to 'LOA Rejected - Action required from client', as this will ensure the update wording is correct.

 

 

Adding checklists to Salesforce:

 

Lastly we need to add in the LOA builder URL link to the Salesforce page.

 

Back in the LOA builder, click ‘Builder Tools’ at the top, then ‘Create Checklists’. You may have to sign in to G-drive, then re-click ‘Builder Tools’ -> ‘Create Checklists’.

 

The plan you added should now be in bold, and underlined. Hover over this, and click the link that appears below it. Once in this page, copy the URL link and add this into Salesforce (see pictures below).

 

For reference, you can see all the policy checklist tabs that have been generated along the bottom of the builder page.

 

 

 

 Check the LOA is linked to a piece of advice.

 

Tick off task (make sure it is in your name before doing so).

Name: Chase fulfilment
OW_task_description__c:
THIS IS OLD PROCESS.


If chasing a transfer:


This task should be kept open while chasing the ceding provider. 


First chase should be carried out 2 weeks after submission. Preferably, you should call a provider to chase the transfer but email is fine if no call centre. After first chase, update fulfilment checklist with date instruction received by ceding provider and the expected completion date. 


Mark task as incomplete and move forward 7 days. We should actively chase the ceding provider and, if necessary, Hubwise/Hartley each week until transfer funds received. 


Once funds are received into Hubwise/Hartley, update the chasing section of the fulfilment checklist which includes:


  • Update IO (for new plans, you will need to add the plan using the guides https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1cUnD8UQS2JZj5mCt5fQCMXQ3-HASQgLH-pGVRGM8LY4/edit#gid=0)
  • Add IO ID to Salesforce products (OW products only)
  • Update PreciseFP
  • Update New Business Register (link is in the fulfilment checklist)
  • Update Salesforce products to show active/closed/transferred statuses, you should also update all relevant fields such as account number, start date, valuation etc (in addition to the IO ID and status)
  • Update Salesforce person account/household to show client is active (instead of onboarding)
  • Email client confirmation of transfer received


Once the above is done, this task can be completed.


If chasing a client payment:


For client lump sum payments: chase the client via email every 7 days. Best practice is to use the payment details template each time but change the intro wording to “Just a friendly reminder….” 


Once a reminder email has been sent, update the “Client payment” section of the fulfilment checklist. You can then change the task status to incomplete and move forward another 7 days. 


Once we have received payment into Hubwise, update the chasing section of the fulfilment checklist which includes:


  • Update IO (for new plans, you will need to add the plan using the guides https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1cUnD8UQS2JZj5mCt5fQCMXQ3-HASQgLH-pGVRGM8LY4/edit#gid=0)
  • Add IO ID to Salesforce products (OW products only)
  • Update PreciseFP
  • Update New Business Register (link is in the fulfilment checklist)
  • Update Salesforce products to show active/closed/transferred statuses, you should also update all relevant fields such as account number, start date, valuation etc (in addition to the IO ID and status)
  • Update Salesforce person account/household to show client is active (instead of onboarding)
  • Email client confirmation of payment received (only for lump sums & transfers - NOT for direct debits/regular contributions)


Once the above is done, this task can be completed.

The purpose of this task is to update all information we hold for a client’s plan across all of our systems. This happens when planning require information to give advice on a plan for the first time, and if valuations expire pre-advice (i.e. are more than 3 months old).

  4. If we cannot access information through the online portal, or have not sent a TOS: Call provider (link to the provider database here) to obtain updated values for all funds and number of units held (and contribution history). Remember to get this in writing as well.
  5.  EOW - Please confirm if there is an EOW on file for the SIPP when you call to get valuaton. Add this info to the internal notes of the FP.

We may need to contact the client directly to gain valuations and contribution history for policies which we can’t LOA - if in doubt, ask planning if this is necessary.

You should also check if the plan is segmented, if so ask for number of segments remaining.

 

  1. Update IO, SF and LOA builder with the latest values.

Name: Chase protection provider
OW_task_description__c:
Assigned to: Specialists Queue

Triggered by: Protection application submission

What this task triggers: Chase client for acceptance of terms

This can be complete when: The terms have been received and shared with client and checklist updated

Due date: Every 7 days

 

Most providers will contact us whenever there is a significant update in an application.

 

In the interim period, we should chase providers to ensure that the application(s) is progressing as expected. If the provider has an online tracking system, you should check there first and, where possible, update chatter.

If they don’t have an online tracking system or the information is limited, you should call the provider to ask for an update. Update chatter.

 

In most cases, the application will be going through standard underwriting processes which can include the provider arranging medical tests for the client with a nurse, and requesting a medical report from the client’s GP.

 

If it appears that a client is not responding to the provider, you should also chase the client via Helpscout, update chatter and move the chase task forward 7 days.

 

If the application is progressing at a reasonable pace, just update chatter and move the chase task forward 7 days.

 

This task should be kept open on a rolling basis until we have received final terms from the provider.

 

Once we receive terms, we need to share them with the client and update the fulfilment checklist. 

 

Terms will either be standard or non-standard and it is important that we understand any changes before sharing them with the client.

 

Once we receive terms, always save these in the relevant 'active policies' folder with the usual conventions. If there is not a file created for the policy then create one.


If the terms are standard and the premiums are within 5% of the original quoted figures: you will need to create a new folder within the client’s Dropbox in order to share the terms and any related documentation with the client. You should then email the client https://docs.google.com/document/d/1h8wjw3cZYU5lpXC8aBYfYCwUM8ih0tRHDflHUWkV5dI/edit

 

If the terms are standard but the premiums are more than 5% of the original quoted figures: you should tag the partner and the original suitability planner in a chatter note in each piece of fulfilment, outlining the final terms, and ask if they want Amy to email the client or for the partner to contact the client instead. Proceed accordingly.

 

If the terms are non-standard: Non-standard terms are likely to include either an exclusion or certain additional criteria that the client would need to satisfy in the event of a claim. This may dramatically impact the suitability of the protection and you should tag the partner and the original suitability planner in a chatter note in each piece of fulfilment and await their instruction on how we should proceed.

 

Once the terms have been shared and the checklist updated, complete this task.

  • Proof of address documents are in date.

  • Confirm proof of identity matches client

  • Validate proof of identity document (this should be a passport)
    • Go to https://worldcheck.refinitiv.com & run a passport check
    • Under Check Types, go to Passport check
    • Fill out all info and follow instructions
    • If this is validated then save passport check report to AML folder



If these are all passed, use the 'TransUnion' button to set the status to 'Pass' - if the docs have allowed you to be comfortable with the risk, this will complete this part of the AML. Ensure that any changes to the profile are made.

This is triggered by all LOAs being moved to completed, cancelled or on hold. This excludes any DB pensions. 

 

At the same time, a task will generate for the Suitability narrative. 

 

To check: 

  • Has the full profile been completed?
  • Have the RTQs been completed?
  • Do we have all the documents we need on file to start advice? E.g. P60s/tax returns, state pension forecasts, budget planner (where mandatory)
  • Do we have all the information we need to start advice? E.g. workplace protection information, salary sacrirfice information.
  • Have all RELEVANT LOAs been completed? (potential for ones with a status of on hold to be needed)
  • Do we have any outstanding queries relating to ISA allowances (such as unconfirmed for cash ISAs)
  • Are there any material prompts in the disco notes for things we should query for the Lifeline? For example, we may want to prompt the partner to discuss plans to change home, have more children or retire early
  • Make sure to include prompts for the partner to do the follow - these last two are specifically needed due to known issues with info changing over the course of a long data gathering period:
    • Review & update/confirm spending in the profile is correct
    • Review & update/confirm cash in the profile is correct
  • Double check if any valuations have already expired in the profile (more than 3 months old) and, if they require client action, include prompts for the partner to request during the call (for example, updated values needed for DIY platforms such as Hargreaves Lansdown, AJ Bell, Vanguard, etc)

Name: Mortgage - AML check
OW_task_description__c:
Only AML once they have signed Terms of Business. You can check this on their person account.


Link the client’s AML folder in the field. 

 

Once AML check has been started, it is your responsibility to keep track of it so keep the task open in your name until AML & KYC have been passed.

 

Experian:

 

  1. Access the Experian website ( https://proveid.experian.com/signin/)
  2. Log in (shared Amy log in details saved in Last Pass)
  3. Input Forename, Other names, Surname, Select 'short entry', Country, Building no., Postcode, Date of Birth
  4. Click 'Search'
  5. Download the results page (print to PDF and save into clients AML file - if decision is 'Accept' save file as: yyyy.mm.dd - surname, forename - Experian PASS/FAIL) Tick the box ‘Final WC1 Reported Saved to Files’

If the client passes the Experian check - update the Experian field to 'Pass', enter the date the check was carried out on and press Save.

 

If the client fails the Experian check -

  • Check to see the reason for the refer:
    • If a client fails Experian with the reason ' Individual has matched on the PEPs Sanctions & Enforcements dataset', we can override this and mark the case as passed. This is because we use World Check 1 to check an individual's possible PEP status.
    • If it’s because their address isn’t registered or their DOB doesn’t match then update the Experian to 'Refer', write any notes for the MRLO to see, enter the date the check was carried out on and press Save. This will generate a task to ‘Request Identity Documents’ (description on task).

 

Once the Identity documents have been received back we can review them. We need to check the following:

  • Check info we hold on file that has been used for checks is correct
    • DOB, name or address could've been mistyped
  • Proof of address documents are in date.
    • Identity Docs (eg driving licence: Not expired
    • Other docs (eg utility bill): dated within 3 months (12 for council tax)
    • If it’s a pdf (has to be source pdf, not picture if it’s banking etc)
    • If scan/photo of doc, need whole doc not zoomed in
    • Has to be an actual statement or bill (ie. not normal letter from bank) 
  • Proof of address documents match address we have on file.
    • If not we should confirm correct address and rerun with the correct one (flag to partner if address differs)
  • Confirm proof of identity matches client
    • If we request a selfie - this can be done by Ops
    • If client seen on video - see if you can find meeting recording and confirm identity matches
  • If seen face to face - contact the partner to confirm identity is correct
    • There is the 'Review Identity documents' task that goes to them which you can use here
  • Validate proof of identity document (this should be a passport)
    • Go to https://worldcheck.refinitiv.com & run a passport check
  • Under Check Types, go to Passport check
    • Fill out all info and follow instructions
    • If this is validated then save passport check report to AML folder

 

If these are all passed we can then move AML check to Pass following review & complete notes section outlining all the above

Review Identity Docs task in Partners name can be completed

 

Diagram to explain flow here: https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1jDWikNZoMaeePpVW0HrBAjBvaf6gxl8GLwmiMAYXFLQ/edit

 

 

WC1:

 

  1. Access the WC1 website ( https://worldcheck.refinitiv.com/)
  2. Log in (shared Amy log in details saved in Last Pass)
  3. Select registration key 'New Team Registration'
  4. Enter (ignore titles Mrs/Mr etc) client full name (including middle name), select gender, enter date of birth, country location and nationality (you can ignore place of birth)
  5. Check the box to enable ongoing screening
  6. Click 'Screen'
  7. Select 'Export' and 'Case report' - download
  8. Upload to AML folder

If no WC1 matches: Update the WC1 to Pass and enter the completed date.

 

If there are WC1 matches:

  1. Use this document that lays out rules from disproving potential matches
  • See if we can gather evidence from client to disprove match.
  • e.g. proof that they were living elsewhere at time or had a different job to a PEP match
    • Write notes explaining how you have disproved match in WC1 & in SF
      • Upload to AML folder
      • You can use meeting recordings to compare images to clients
    • Then mark any matches as false
    • Select 'Export' and 'Case report' - download
  1. If you cannot disprove the matches, update the WC1 to Fail, add any notes as to why the client failed, and enter the completed date. The MLRO will have a task to review this. 
  • This should be a very last resort. It is very unlikely that this would be the case.
    • I would flag with someone from ops before moving to fail.

 

 

HTAR Matrix: 

 

  • If the HTAR Matrix Risk Level fields are not filled out, refresh the page. If this doesn't change then flag it on "prod-salesforce channel."
  • If the HTAR matrix is anything other than Average risk, check to see that the “MLRO to review HTAR Matrix” task has generated for MRLO.
  • If client flagged as HTAR then request identity docs using this template
  • Tag partner and planner (if case assigned to one) to flag this as they will need to have a discussion on what is required to ensure client is OK to proceed
    • This will depend on advise being given so there is no blanket rule as to what is required.

 

Link to HTAR Matrix: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1BH_tMEZ2wXYZbPs5hOYpjyYQStSBvB2xi9VChSVHAys/edit#gid=695178989

 

The current AML Policy is here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1r7XtMVeu0r4itGXwRBf2ZUrE1yFG5cMi4x7Sql-OjgY/edit

OW_task_description__c:
The purpose of this task is to send a reminder to the client to complete their fact-find.


N.B: Once you chased, press the push (action taken) button and choose a new due date.


  • Check status on Profile Updates Tab to ensure chaser task is relevant
  • Double check to ensure no profile validations are outstanding by checking profile updates or even if there is a task for the planners to validate. If there are validations outstanding ask a planner to validate these before sending a chaser email as we don’t want to request information the client has already provided
  • If not first attempt, can copy, paste & update the previous chaser emails (check SF & Helpscout)
  • If the first attempt & follow on advice, check narrative on advice to see what specifically to chase (i.e. protection info, cash update)
    • If the client has never activated their questionnaire, then check their profile on salesforce to see if they have activated their account. If not send them another link.


  • Discovery meeting chaser templates here. If the partners have previously been in touch about a meeting, use the 'First chase' templates
  • Draft the email and leave a tag on it for someone to review and send.


There are 3 places to look on salesforce for the information we need:

  1. The client & their partner’s individual profiles for:
    1. Date of birth
    2. Marriage status
    3. Retirement target
    4. Spending & saving 
    5. Discovery Level of Risk
  2. Household >> Profile
    1. Person accounts (a summary of all of the above)
    2. Employment (earnings for both client & partner)
    3. Financial accounts (need a current / savings account)
    4. Assets (expect to see one property & require value. If a rental property then need income)
    5. Liabilities (expect to see a mortgage. If not, check age as might be older and paid one off)
  3. Household >> Details
    1. Check the field ‘Planning to have more children’
  • When planners have the task to validate anything new a client adds to their profile, they can’t complete the task until they change the status in Profile Updates to either ‘Up to date’ or ‘Update required’.
  • Check to see if the clients have any children. If yes, go into the child’s person account and look for their Date of birth and also the cost of childcare & education. 
  • If they have given no financial products ask in the email:
    • "Please can you provide details of your investments and savings? (e.g. pensions, cash accounts, ISAs, protection policies or other investments)


If the discovery FF looks majority complete, flag with a planner for the next steps (I.e. some missing info may not be required for the specific piece of advice)


IMPORTANT:

The disco team cannot create a personalised disco without the following:

  1. Date of birth
  2. Retirement target
  3. Spending
  4. Employment
  5. Financial accounts - can technically do without them, but then what is the point of the disco?

 

Assets & liabilities have not been included as we can technically proceed without, however, disco may not be of much value if the client does have these and they are not included in LL.

 

If we have everything we need then move the status to up-to-date and complete the task.

Name: Validate full profile client updates
OW_task_description__c:
Validate full profile client updates


Validation Process


Link to validations guide


Navigate to Household > Profile Updates. You will see that each FF object has a “Validated” Column, if this is blank then it is a new entry and the record needs to be validated. 


Click into the FF record, and you’ll see the data stored in it and the Validation Section. 


Validated Options 


  • Validated - Marking a record as Validated will push the changes into the corresponding SF record, or it will create a new SF record if one does not already exist.
  • Rejected - This will reject the changes and the client’s profile will revert back to the most recent validated record. 
  • Confirm Deletion - The client has deleted a record from their portal. If you confirm this deletion it will be removed from SF
  • Overwritten - This option is only ever selected automatically when a client makes multiple changes to the same record. 


Once all outstanding FF records have been either Validated or Rejected you will be able to close of the task off and be able to make changes to SF records as normal. 


If you believe that the profile has been completed, change the status to Up-to-date


Profile Status


This status is purely for internal operations visibility, the status will be updated automatically where possible, but otherwise, it’s a manual status that you can use to indicate the status of the profile. No automation will be triggered by changing this status. 


  • Update Required - The profile needs to be updated but the client has not yet been informed of this. This is the default status when a Household is first created and will revert back to this status once they have accepted scope. You can also move it to this stage manually if there is every a requirement for the client to update the profile
  • Sent to Client(s) - Designates that clients are aware that they need to update their profile. For Disco’s this will update automatically once a client it first sent the profile. 
  • Updated by Client (Validations Outstanding) - The client has made changes to their profile but they have not marked it as complete. 
  • Completed by Client (Validations Outstanding) - The client has made changes to their profile and marked it as complete. 

Up-to-date - Manually select this stage once we have everything we need. It will remain in the stage until we need a new update or the client spontaneously updates their profile.


After you update the profile to Up-to-Date, add in the comments of the Add Full Fact Find to IO task that generates what has been updated. this will make it easier to update IO

Name: Update Valuation
OW_task_description__c:
The purpose of this task is to update all information we hold for a client’s plan across all of our systems. This happens when planning require information to give advice on a plan for the first time, and if valuations expire pre-advice (i.e. are more than 3 months old).
 
  1. Call provider (link to the provider database here) to obtain updated values for all funds, number of units held and the relevant SEDOLs (If NA, please request fund factsheets). Remember to get this in writing as well.
  2. Check if we sent a TOS or LOA for the client’s policy
  3. If we sent a TOS to the provider: if the provider is Aegon, Aviva, Legal & General, Royal London, or Standard Life, follow the portal link in this spreadsheet. Once logged in, search the client’s name and download an up-to-date valuation directly from the portal.
  4. If we cannot access information through the online portal, or have not sent a TOS: Call provider (link to the provider database here) to obtain updated values for all funds and number of units held. Remember to get this in writing as well.
  5.  EOW - Please confirm if there is an EOW on file for the SIPP when you call to get valuaton. Add this info to the internal notes of the FP.


We may need to contact the client directly to gain valuations for policies which we can’t LOA - if in doubt, ask planning if this is necessary.
You should also check if the plan is segmented, if so ask for number of segments remaining.
 
  1. Update IO, SF and LOA builder with the latest values. 

Chatters
All chatters should contain the following information:
  1. Contact number called
  2. First and second name of who you spoke to.
  3. Date and time of call (approx. time is fine)
  4. If you get a valuation, please also get the date of the value


﻿Please make a copy of the template here when receiving information over the phone. Save this copy in the policy folder G drive.

Name: Update Valuation, History and Performance
OW_task_description__c:
The purpose of this task is to update all information we hold for a client’s plan across all of our systems, as well as producing updated fund performance analysis using a new suitability builder. This happens when planning require information to give advice on a plan for the first time, and if valuations expire pre-advice (i.e. are more than 3 months old).

 

  1. Call provider (link to the provider database here) to obtain updated values for all funds, number of units held and the relevant SEDOLs (If NA, please request fund factsheets). Also obtain an updated contribution history. Remember to get this in writing as well.
  2. Check if we sent a TOS or LOA for the client’s policy
  3. If we sent a TOS to the provider: if the provider is Aegon, Aviva, Legal & General, Royal London, or Standard Life, follow the portal link in this spreadsheet. Once logged in, search the client’s name and download an up-to-date valuation and contribution history directly from the portal.
  4. If we cannot access information through the online portal, or have not sent a TOS: Call provider (link to the provider database here) to obtain updated values for all funds and number of units held. Also obtain an updated contribution history. Remember to get this in writing as well.

We may need to contact the client directly to gain valuations and contribution history for policies which we can’t LOA - if in doubt, ask planning if this is necessary.

You should also check if the plan is segmented, if so ask for number of segments remaining.
